awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Understanding the controls on spatial and temporal variability in ice discharge using a Greenland-wide ice sheet model

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Satellite observations over the last two decades have documented an increase mass loss of the Greenland ice sheet that is accompanied by speed-up, thinning, and retreat of Greenland?s marine-terminating outlet glaciers. These changes have occurred quasi-synchronous with increased access of warm subsurface waters in many of Greenland?s deep fjords. These waters are of subtropical North Atlantic origin, carried with the North Atlantic Drift into the subpolar regions. The impact of increased mass loss, i.e., increased freshwater discharge from Greenland into the subpolar North Atlantic on the gyre and meridional overturning circulation remains poorly understood but is believed to play a significant role on the basin-wide coupled atmosphere-ocean system on climatic time scale.

Ocean models display strong sensitivity in both amplitude and location to freshwater input into the subolar North Atlantic from both Greenland freshwater discharge as well as freshwater export from the Arctic Mediterranean (due to Arctic river runoff and sea ice melt), that can lead to rapid changes in overturning circulation and heat transport in the North Atlantic. For the Greenland Ice Sheet, freshwater flux into the ocean arises from surface melt, melting of marine terminating glaciers, and calving of the glacier?s ice front. Surface melt that is routed to the ice-bedrock and enters the ocean at depth (i.e. subglacial runoff) can dramatically increase melt rates at the ice front due to enhanced mixing associated with a rising turbulent buoyant plume that entrains ambient warm water. Other controlling factors include bed topography, in particular the presence or absence of important sills at the mouth between the fjord and the continental shelf.

In light of the importance of freshwater flux on global ocean circulation careful treatment of surface runoff and glacial processes (i.e. calving and submarine melting) are critical for assessing the modern ocean state. Our work focused on investigating and improving the representation of freshwater flux in a regional Arctic-subpolar North Atlantic simulation and state estimation framework by transitioning from climatological estimates to modern observations of freshwater discharge estimates. Furthermore, we have used subglacial runoff estimates to model enhanced freshwater formation for Greenland?s largest glaciers. Since the computational cost of resolving fjord-scale systems in global ocean models is prohibitive, we leverage sub-gridscale plume models within our ocean model to represent submarine melting of the finer-scale glacier systems. This includes using fjord and glacier properties such as ice draft and sill depths along the fjord. 

Results from our simulations using different freshwater forcing configurations show that largescale circulation (e.g. subpolar gyre strength, overturning circulation strength) is strongly sensitive to the distribution and delivery of freshwater flux in the Arctic, even at coarse grid resolution. While our sub-gridscale plume model improves the statistics and captures the seasonal variability of glacial melt rates around Greenland, at coarse grid resolutions careful treatment of these models is necessary due to the strong sensitivity of the ocean model to enhanced mixing, as well as buoyant plume parameterization. Improved knowledge and parameterization schemes are likely key for advancing coupled climate-ice sheet model simulations in support of the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project, Phase 7, anticipated for the end of this decade.

Modified by: Patrick Heimbach
